trans-unit.source: Set up your Service Fabric development environment | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Set up your Service Fabric development environment | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Install the Service Fabric runtime, SDK, and tools and create a local development cluster.
trans-unit.target: Install the Service Fabric runtime, SDK, and tools and create a local development cluster.

trans-unit.source: Set up your Service Fabric development environment
trans-unit.target: Set up your Service Fabric development environment

trans-unit.source: This article covers everything you need to start building [Service Fabric][1] apps, including installing the runtime, SDK, tools, and setting up a local cluster.
trans-unit.target: This article covers everything you need to start building [Service Fabric][1] apps, including installing the runtime, SDK, tools, and setting up a local cluster.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] These instructions are intended for setting up new PCs.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] These instructions are intended for setting up new PCs.

trans-unit.source: If you have installed a previous version of Service Fabric on your PC, please follow the [instructions to update your development environment ](service-fabric-update-your-development-environment.md).
trans-unit.target: If you have installed a previous version of Service Fabric on your PC, please follow the [instructions to update your development environment ](service-fabric-update-your-development-environment.md).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Supported Operating System versions
trans-unit.target: Supported Operating System versions

trans-unit.source: The following operating system versions are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following operating system versions are supported:

trans-unit.source: Windows 8/8.1
trans-unit.target: Windows 8/8.1

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

trans-unit.source: Windows 10
trans-unit.target: Windows 10

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015

trans-unit.source: The tools for Service Fabric depend on Visual Studio 2015, which you can find [here][2].
trans-unit.target: The tools for Service Fabric depend on Visual Studio 2015, which you can find [here][2].

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you aren't running one of the supported OS versions or would prefer not to install Visual Studio 2015 on your PC, you can set up an Azure virtual machine with Windows Server 2012 R2 and Visual Studio 2015 pre-installed using an image from the VM Gallery.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you aren't running one of the supported OS versions or would prefer not to install Visual Studio 2015 on your PC, you can set up an Azure virtual machine with Windows Server 2012 R2 and Visual Studio 2015 pre-installed using an image from the VM Gallery.

trans-unit.source: Install the runtime, SDK, and tools
trans-unit.target: Install the runtime, SDK, and tools

trans-unit.source: Installation of the Service Fabric components is done by the Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: Installation of the Service Fabric components is done by the Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: Follow these instructions to install:
trans-unit.target: Follow these instructions to install:

trans-unit.source: [Download the SDK][3] using the Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: [Download the SDK][3] using the Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: Click **Install** to begin the install process.
trans-unit.target: Click **Install** to begin the install process.

trans-unit.source: Review and accept the EULA.
trans-unit.target: Review and accept the EULA.

trans-unit.source: Installation will proceed automatically.
trans-unit.target: Installation will proceed automatically.

trans-unit.source: Enable PowerShell script execution
trans-unit.target: Enable PowerShell script execution

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric uses Windows PowerShell scripts for creating a local development cluster and for deploying applications from Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric uses Windows PowerShell scripts for creating a local development cluster and for deploying applications from Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: By default, Windows will block these scripts from running.
trans-unit.target: By default, Windows will block these scripts from running.

trans-unit.source: To enable them, you must modify your PowerShell execution policy.
trans-unit.target: To enable them, you must modify your PowerShell execution policy.

trans-unit.source: Open PowerShell as an administrator and enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: Open PowerShell as an administrator and enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: Install and start a local cluster
trans-unit.target: Install and start a local cluster

trans-unit.source: A local cluster represents the multi-machine topology that you will eventually use in production on a single development machine.
trans-unit.target: A local cluster represents the multi-machine topology that you will eventually use in production on a single development machine.

trans-unit.source: To set up the local cluster, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To set up the local cluster, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Close all other PowerShell windows and start a new one as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: Close all other PowerShell windows and start a new one as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the cluster setup directory with `cd "$env:ProgramW6432\Microsoft SDKs\Service Fabric\ClusterSetup"`
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the cluster setup directory with `cd "$env:ProgramW6432\Microsoft SDKs\Service Fabric\ClusterSetup"`

trans-unit.source: Run `.\DevClusterSetup.ps1`
trans-unit.target: Run `.\DevClusterSetup.ps1`

trans-unit.source: In a few moments you should see output that shows node information and confirmation that the cluster was created successfully.
trans-unit.target: In a few moments you should see output that shows node information and confirmation that the cluster was created successfully.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you may see warnings while the Service Fabric Host Service and Naming Services start up.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you may see warnings while the Service Fabric Host Service and Naming Services start up.

trans-unit.source: These are normal and will be followed momentarily by some basic information about the cluster.
trans-unit.target: These are normal and will be followed momentarily by some basic information about the cluster.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Your local cluster uses exactly the same runtime as what will run in Azure.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Your local cluster uses exactly the same runtime as what will run in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It is not simulated or emulated in any way.
trans-unit.target: It is not simulated or emulated in any way.

trans-unit.source: The only difference is that all of your nodes run on a single machine, rather than being distributed across multiple machines as they will be in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The only difference is that all of your nodes run on a single machine, rather than being distributed across multiple machines as they will be in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Validate your cluster setup
trans-unit.target: Validate your cluster setup

trans-unit.source: You can check that your cluster was created successfully using the Service Fabric Explorer tool that ships with the SDK.
trans-unit.target: You can check that your cluster was created successfully using the Service Fabric Explorer tool that ships with the SDK.

trans-unit.source: Start the Service Fabric Explorer by running `. "$env:ProgramW6432\Microsoft SDKs\Service Fabric\Tools\ServiceFabricExplorer\ServiceFabricExplorer.exe"`.
trans-unit.target: Start the Service Fabric Explorer by running `. "$env:ProgramW6432\Microsoft SDKs\Service Fabric\Tools\ServiceFabricExplorer\ServiceFabricExplorer.exe"`.

trans-unit.source: Expand the Onebox/Local Cluster node in the top-left corner.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Onebox/Local Cluster node in the top-left corner.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the Application and Node views are green.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the Application and Node views are green.

trans-unit.source: If any element is not green or you see an error, wait a few moments and click the refresh button.
trans-unit.target: If any element is not green or you see an error, wait a few moments and click the refresh button.

trans-unit.source: If you still have issues, check out the [setup troubleshooting steps](service-fabric-troubleshoot-local-cluster-setup.md).
trans-unit.target: If you still have issues, check out the [setup troubleshooting steps](service-fabric-troubleshoot-local-cluster-setup.md).

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that your development environment is set up, you can start building and running apps.
trans-unit.target: Now that your development environment is set up, you can start building and running apps.

trans-unit.source: Learn about the programming models: Reliable Actors and Reliable Services
trans-unit.target: Learn about the programming models: Reliable Actors and Reliable Services

trans-unit.source: Get started with the Reliable Services API
trans-unit.target: Get started with the Reliable Services API

trans-unit.source: Get started with the Reliable Actors API
trans-unit.target: Get started with the Reliable Actors API

trans-unit.source: Check out the Service Fabric samples on GitHub
trans-unit.target: Check out the Service Fabric samples on GitHub

trans-unit.source: Visualize your cluster using Service Fabric Explorer
trans-unit.target: Visualize your cluster using Service Fabric Explorer
